awd_titl_txt: ATD: Collaborative Research: Real-Time Network Pattern Change Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapidly booming amounts of social networks data from the Internet offers a lot of information to understand human behaviors. First, the networks data contains sparse communication frequencies and some dense clusters, and the clusters change over time, so that feature generation and selection are essential. This research project addresses the statistical challenges for detecting abrupt categories changes in networks. This is important for quantifying human dynamics and accurately identifying unusual events and forecast future threats indicated by those events. Graduate students will be involved in some aspects of the project.

This project aims to develop 1) for the static case: we will use zero-inflated or hurdle models to characterize the class link probability. 2) for the dynamic case: the class communication probability is a variable of time, we model the probability by a self-exciting process. 3) we consider the cold-start problem in which the predicted networks vary a lot from the training network, so that there are no enough samples to train classification models. Instead, we will develop matrix-variate clustering and classification models. This project includes several important topics to improve modeling of the network users' categories and identifying efficiently abrupt network pattern changes in real time as well as reducing the influence of outliers. These methods are applicable to various types of networks data such as social networks, biology signals, genome sequences, and so on. The PIs will provide a publicly-available software packages to implement the proposed methods. Additionally, corresponding statistical theories and computational techniques can be extended to advance further research and can be applied to other fields. This project topics cater to the students with hands-on studies in new Big-Data analysis program at the University of Central Florida.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed study, entitled ATD: Collaborative Research: Real-Time Network Pattern Change Detection, developed statistical models and efficient algorithms for analyzing zero-inflated count data, longitudinal count data, high-dimensional sparse data, categorical data, and massive data, as well as clustering and detecting anomaly activities. The developed statistical methods and algorithms can find the most appropriate statistical models for zero-inflated data and have been successfully applied to network data, real-time traffic data, insurance data, microbiome data, and genetic data. The developed clustering technique can identify clusters invariant to arbitrary nonsingular linear transformations and has been used for a 3D road network data. The developed score-matching representative approach provides a highly efficient algorithm for massive data analysis and has been used for the on-time performance data of the US domestic flights. The developed impact measure for accidents of traffic flows provides a scientific measurement of the severity of accidents, which may help the public to gain a better understanding of the accidents and the traffic status, as well as helping the transportation authority to improve the traffic management.

During the proposal period, 09/01/2019 - 08/31/2023, the proposed study has led to 10 papers published or accepted in peer-reviewed prestigious journals, 4 PhD dissertations, and 2 computer packages. The PI and his PhD students have presented their findings in 4 research seminars and 9 conference presentations. The two computer packages, iZID and AZIAD, have been published at the public-accessible website Comprehensive R Archive Network (https://cran.r-project.org/) and have been downloaded 15,338 and 4,519 times as on November 29, 2023, respectively.
